body:
Global Voices contributors are often called on by international media to help explain breaking news events. As Tunisian protests gained momentum in January, we were first dismayed that there seemed to be little mainstream media interest and later overwhelmed by media requests. I thought it would be useful to share an overview of where Global Voices authors and editors have been interviewed or featured in mainstream media about the Tunisian protests since it's sometimes hard to quantify what effect our work has. I think this helps show one way we collectively influence the global public conversation about citizen and social media in times of crisis.

Global Voices can't take credit for the work individual contributors do in their own blogs and local online networks. But part of what defines us as a community is how we pull together in moments of crisis and advise and inform each other. It's clear in our daily work, email and Twitter conversations, that we all share a sense of pride when Global Voices friends are able to voice their perspectives to an international audience.

Is social media driving reform?

Al Jazeera's evening talk show host Riz Khan spoke to Sami Ben Gharbia, Global Voices Advocacy Director and co-founder of the Tunisian website Nawaat.org, blogger Nasser Weddady, who is also the outreach director at the American Islamic Congress; and Wael Abbas, an Egyptian blogger and activist.



Sami Ben Gharbia appeared in interviews with several other publications, including Newsweek and Al Jazeera English as did Tunisian blogger and Global Voices author Lina Ben Mhenni. Both also appeared in posts on The New York Times new blog, The Lede. So did Slim Amamoun.
 
Lina was also interviewed by CNN, Al Jazeera, Voice of America, and The Financial Times (subscription only).

On NPR's On the Media Lina described being followed around by not-so-secret Tunisian police.
